question.para: Let \Vect{x} = (x,y) be a vector in \RNr[2]. What values of the direction angles \omega_1 and \omega_2 are possible if
\Vect{x} is a first quadrant vector; i.e. if x,y > 0 ?

info.caption: Comment on: \omega_1 = \omega_2 = 90 degrees
info.para: Sorry, no! - A vector with this property would have to lie simultaneously on the \Vect{e}_1-axis and on the \Vect{e}_2-axis. Only the \Vect{0}-vector has this property. But for the \Vect{0}-vector direction angles are not defined.

question.para: \Vect{x} is a second quadrant vector; i.e. if x < 0 and y > 0 ?

info.caption: Comment on \pi < \omega_1 < 3\pi/2 and 0 < \omega_2 < \pi/2
info.para: Sorry, no! - By definition, direction angles are between 0 and \pi. So this answer cannot be correct.
